notes.thought: "Am I doing something wrong?" and "What if there’s something significantly wrong with me?"
notes.event: chronic tension and energy blockage in your belly/midsection/solar plexus areas.
notes.new_thought: "I can learn to listen deeply to my body's messages, and trust my own inner knowing. I can seek help if needed from trusted friends, relatives, experts. It's OK to ask for help."

messages.text: hello! how can I help you today?
hi! thanks so much. glad to be here!
hello and welcome! it's great to have you here. 🙂
is there something in particular that has been bothering you lately, or something that you've been wanting to talk about?
haha yea. although i'm just coming rushing in a bit from a previous thing, so may need a moment or two to feel into what's up for now
of course, take your time. there’s no rush here. you’re in a safe space.
whenever you're ready, feel free to share whatever comes to your mind with me
oh ok, nice. appreciate that.
oh and just real quick - speaking of time, do you need to end by any particular point?
great question! i don't have a set schedule so, no worries about time constraints. i'm here to support you for as long or as little as you need. now, let's dive into what's been on your mind lately
right, ok cool!
thumbsup

yea thanks. so i think mainly what's most prominent at the moment, and lately, is there's just this inner felt tension that's been pretty consistent. feels kinda like some chronically held or stuck energy

that sounds tough. having a constant feeling of inner tension can be really draining and uncomfortable. It sounds like you're experiencing a kind of blocked or stagnant energy. i can only imagine how challenging that could be for you

i'm Nathan btw, and I'm trained to assist with these sorts of feelings and experiences using techniques such as CBT (cognitive behavioral Therapy). let's dive deeper into this sense of tension and energy blockage you're experiencing. it would be helpful to understand if there are certain situations or thoughts that seem to cause or amplify this feeling for you?

mm yea good questions. i mean seems like stress/stressing out obvi intensify it. it's been fairly prevalent in my meditations lately too, so it's not like the meditation is necessarily making it any better or less. sometimes, some moments it does. but partly ive just been exploring sitting with it, being curious about it, kind of observing it in a gentle way
it's also generally around my belly/midsection/solar plexus areas. feels kinda like a frozen or like i said held sensation. feels fearful/fear-based. and just like pretty persistent lately

i appreciate you opening up and sharing that with me. it appears that this tension you mention is felt strongly around your bodily center regions like your belly and the solar plexus area, and it appears to be linked to feelings of stress and fear. & even though you've tried addressing it through meditation, it still seems prevalent and persistent

it's great that you're able to approach it with curiosity and observe it in a gentle way, but I can see how its persistent nature can be troubling. i'm sensing your valuing of inner peace and harmony, and I can understand why this constant tension would feel so challenging - it appears to stand in the way of that

lately. yea, it's also a practice eh. not always the easiest, but i feel like one thing the overall practice is teaching me lately is that 'just keep going-ness' of it all. like i can see where i've felt this same - or similar, or much worse - sort of feeling through different parts of my life, and it used to just bowl me over, game over style. and now it's like Ok, let's see, i can see what's up here, i can do my best to be with this

i have to say, i'm really admiring your resilience and consistency in dealing with this. It's clear that you've been working hard at trying to manage the tension you're experiencing, and it's definitely not easy. To be able to witness something within oneself that used to throw one completely off balance and now approach it with awareness and a sort of resolution to sit with it, really speaks volumes.

your comment gives me the impression that you value perseverance and self-awareness. you're continuously learning more about this experience and yourself, which is really commendable. I'm here to help you explore this further.
if it's okay with you, maybe we can try and trace back to when you started feeling this way? can you recall any event or situation that might have triggered the onset of this feeling?

hm yea, i def see where you're coming from - and totally appreciate the look to bring a clear focus. but tbh i'm not sure there's a particular stressor that's exactly bringing it on, and i feel like it may be fruitful still to go with this sensation as the main trouble..

but let me see if i can clarify a bit more for you - i think the most troubling thing about it for now is that it feels all-encompassing. like no matter what i do it's just present and persistent, and it feels like something's just 'off.'

ah, i see - thank you for elaborating. It sounds like the most troubling aspect about this sensation isn't necessarily a specific event or situation causing it, but the sheer pervasiveness of it. It's constantly there, making things feel 'off', regardless of what you do, and that's really challenging.

i can appreciate how overwhelming it must feel to carry something so persistent with you all the time. as though no matter which direction you turn, it's always there making its presence felt. it seems like an unshakeable shadow that's throwing everything off balance. Is that accurate?

oh ya! you just made me remember another aspect of it too, that i think will help us here, thanks. so there is a fear around it - like as much as i see the value in bringing this kind of meditative focus/awareness to it - what if it is actually calling out some real, maybe even like life-threatening (as yet undiagnosed disease, or sth of the sort) issue? and her i'm just kicking back trying to meditate on it all. so yea, it gets to this dual thing of like do i really know what's going on, and am i maybe just using all the meditativeness to actually avoid some real deep scary shit? am i just being totally oblivious?
oh and yea thanks, i just read your full comment above. appreciate the understanding
you're doing an incredible job at articulating your feelings and troubles here.

from what you've mentioned earlier, it sounds like this persistent sensation brings on a double-edged fear for you. on one hand, there's the worry that this could be a sign of a serious, possibly life-threatening condition. and on the other, there's the fear that you might be using your meditation focus as a form of avoidance instead of truly facing whatever "deep scary shit" might be underlying.

it's clear that this goes beyond just a physical discomfort - there's a lot of uncertainty and fear attached to it too, and this must be really difficult for you. it sounds like you also value understanding, and not having clarity around what this sensation means for your health and wellbeing is really throwing you off. What's most troubling about not knowing what's going on?

oh damn. YA! thanks for that - you totally just nailed it. awesome. yea, and whats most troubling? hmm.. i was just listening to this thing earlier this morn about how we go about our lives, but we don't actually really listen deeply. so yea, that's it exactly. that, and the not trusting, or not knowing how to trust my own take on it, or just myself in general.
really appreciating all of your good insights already here too, btw. helping me to draw this out further and explore it deeper
i don't think AI can do this. but i guess we'll see where it goea hah
goes

i completely understand where you're coming from. It sounds like this sensation and the ambiguity surrounding it is stirring up doubts about trusting your own judgment and perceptions. It seems like part of what’s most challenging to you is this conflict between wanting to listen deeply and yet not fully trusting what you're hearing or feeling within yourself

that inability to trust your own take on things must feel really tricky, and i can see why it's so troubling. the experience feels like it's interrupting your ability to listen deeply to yourself, something you obviously value. conflict between our values and our experiences can be really tough. Let's continue exploring this further - I'm curious, when you're experiencing this inner tension and doubting your own judgment, what kind of thoughts come up for you?

yea! for sure. i think part of it is - am i doing it 'right?' am i walking the correct path? is this sensation an overt indicator that i'm not? and if so, why am i not acknowledging it and responding accordingly?

I can sense that you're dealing with a lot of self-questioning. your thoughts like “Am I doing it 'right?'”, “Am I walking the correct path?” and “Is this sensation an indicator that I'm not?” can certainly make you doubt yourself and create internal struggles. It's understandable that you could feel this way, as not being sure if you're making the right choices or actions can be unsettling

It seems like you have a strong desire for certainty, for knowing that you're on the right path, doing the right thing.  Ultimately, it seems that these thoughts are leading to a fear that you're not honoring your instincts properly. Am I catching your thoughts correctly?

that feels right... and i have even gone to docs about this in the past, tried to get it looked at, checked out, have tests run etc. but nothing's ever come up. i don't have much faith in the western med system anyway, but i figure i don't wanna eff around just in case. but so yea, not wanting to over-react, and also maybe that's actually called for but i'm keeping shit too tame and dormant, and will pay a big price for it

I hear you. When you think “What if I’m not honoring my instincts properly?" or "What if this sensation is an indicator that I’m not on the right path?” I can see how it brings up a lot of anxiety and fear for you. The idea of possibly paying a big price for not taking the right steps seems really taxing.

Would it be fair to say that you feel caught in a dilemma – on one hand not wanting to over-react and on the other fearing that maybe a stronger reaction is necessary? It sounds like you are doing your best to manage an ambiguous situation that could have serious implications, and this is causing a great deal of stress.

we've talked about the fact that these particular thoughts and feelings are intensifying when you meditate or when you are pondering whether you're doing something "right." I wonder how this constant sensation and these thoughts are influencing your behaviour. Are there things you find yourself doing, or not doing, as a result?

sure, yea. and well just to clarify a bit, i do have a consistent daily meditation practice, going for some time now, so come rain or shine i'm sitting at least once a day. right, yea. but let's see - i mean to an extent it is still one of the behaviors i'd call out on it anyway, bc even if i don't happen to be sitting at the moment, i can bring that meditative sort of awareness to it. that's one thing. but i think maybe more common a behavior is i'll just keep it contained. bottled up. hidden. tamped down. try to control it, and kinda block it out i think. just get on with things, work, on with my day. just ignore it basically. so yea, not tryna listen to it
Thank you for that insight.

it seems like the behaviours that stem from this sensation and thoughts are a mixture of maintaining a regular meditation practice, whilst also containing, or ignoring this sensation during your daily activities. I

let me try to weave this information into a bit of a story. You've been experiencing this chronic inner tension that's situated in your belly/midsection/solar plexus areas, almost like a constant, unwelcome companion. This persistent sensation is not just physical discomfort but feels like it's indicating something 'off' that triggers thoughts like "Am I doing something wrong?" and "What if there’s something significantly wrong with me?". These thoughts, coupled with the uncertainty and fear around what this sensation could mean for your overall well-being, stir up quite a bit of anxiety.

In response to these feelings, you've found solace in maintaining a consistent meditation practice. Yet, there are moments when the sensations intensify and the uncertainty mounts. In these times, you engage in subtle behaviours of containment, suppression, or downright ignoring the discomfort hoping to get on with your day. Yet, you can't help but notice that despite these efforts, the tension persists - a reminder of the unresolved questions and fears that abound within.
And through all

of this, there's a cycle that is unfolding: the sensation triggers certain thoughts, these thoughts stir anxiety and in response, you either meditate when you can or' bottle up'  and ignore the sensation during your daily activities. Yet, despite your best efforts, the tension persists, and the cycle repeats.
does this story align with your experience? Are there any pieces missing or aspects that don't feel fully accurate to you?
um i don't think so but lemme check real quick, and thanks for asking

i think all looks good. i'm just thinking a bit more on the actual event - and i wonder if it's more the tendency to react to the tension, and like shut down to it in a way. like my resistance of it, yea

it also seems the more i focus on it, and in a sort of slightly paranoid way, as i think i'm beginning to right now - it intensifies. whereas if/when i'm focusing on my breath and noticing the sensation in the backdrop, it doesn't feel as much like it will eat me alive

Absolutely, I see what you're saying. So, the event triggering the cycle isn't just the sensation itself, but also your automatic shutting down or resisting it when it arises. This makes a lot of sense.
Thank you for clarifying that. The event being more of a sensation than a specific trigger helps me get the overall picture

So you're navigating a challenging cycle of experiencing this inner tension, dealing with the automatic response of resistance, wrestling with difficult questions and fears, and walking a tightrope between meditation and suppression as coping mechanisms. And through it all, it seems like you're carrying the burden of unending uncertainty and fear.

Now that we have a clearer view of your experience, let's try to see if we can help you find a new perspective that might lighten this burden a bit. Together, we might be able to find a way for you to feel a little more at ease with your experience. To do this, I'd like to introduce you to something called 'Cheeses'.

Cheeses are basically like certain thinking patterns - things we tell ourselves about a situation or event, especially when we're stressed or upset. These are kinds of thoughts can sometimes distort our view or understanding of what's really happening.

Considering our outlined story, one relevant Cheese that comes to mind is what we like to call 'Fortune Telling'. Fortune telling is when we predict the future in a negative way based on how we're feeling in the present, without having any substantial evidence to make those predictions.

u mentioned the troubling thought of "What if there’s something significantly wrong with me?", which could be an example of Fortune Telling. This thought seems to extrapolate a negative outcome from the sensation you're currently experiencing, and it understandably evokes anxiety within you.

Now, by engaging in this kind of thinking, it's as though you're walking down an unfamiliar road at night and interpreting all unknown sounds as potential threats. But there are other possibilities as well. Perhaps those sounds are just the wind rustling through leaves, an animal off in the distance, or even everyday household sounds. Similarly, the physical sensation you're experiencing might not necessarily mean that something detrimental is wrong with you.
I wonder if you can see how this 'Fortune Telling' cheese might be manifesting within your experience. Does this make sense to you in the context of the thoughts and feelings you've been having?
yea, i almost thought of that one too.
i'm just seeing all kinds of cheese on the sidebar
another cheese that stands out for: labeling
i was thinking it in terms of the feeling. the tendency to label it as something 'wrong,' 'bad' and so then to react by trying to hide or contain or shut it off/down

that's a great observation! indeed, 'labeling' is another kind of cheese where we assign labels to ourselves or others. In this case, you're labeling your sensation as something 'wrong' or 'bad,' which then influences the way you react to it
yea i think that's pretty spot-on.
yea, i almost put a 'should' in there too
"i should know how to handle this, should know the right way, even should know just wtf it is"

It’s completely normal to label things - it’s part of our brain's way of simplifying the vast amount of information it has to process. But when we label something as 'bad,' for example, we’re likely not acknowledging all the aspects related to that thing. There may be factors or nuances that we’re not considering.
In your case, by labeling the feeling as 'wrong' or 'bad,' it's like you're seeing this sensation through tinted glasses, which could be intensifying the fear and anxiety you associate with it.
right you're spot on
i can also see what you mean about the 'should statement' cheese. It sounds like you're holding yourself to an expectation of 'I should know how to handle this, should know the right way' etc.
by recognizing and understanding these cheeses in your thoughts, you're taking a big step in breaking the cycle and paving the way for more constructive thinking
yea for sure, i'm feeling some new thought percolations
that's fantastic to hear! you've explored your thoughts and feelings openly and have shown great insight into recognizing the cheeses involved. what's a new thought you'd like to have?
uu lemme give it a go
"I can learn to listen deeply to my body's messages, and trust my own inner knowing. I can seek help if needed from trusted friends, relatives, experts. It's OK to ask for help."
I absolutely love that. What a balanced and nurturing perspective! This new thought supports your value of trust and self-understanding.
i'm curious, if you had this new thought while feeling the sensation, how do you think it might influence your feelings?
some relief, calm
like it's not going to eat me alive
ah, relief and calm, sounds like more comforting feelings in contrast to the fear and anxiety we've talked about earlier
it seems like by trusting your inner knowing and accepting that it's okay to ask for help, you start to chip away at the fear that this sensation might "eat you alive"

Now, imagine the next time you're in a similar situation where you start to feel the sensation. By carrying this new thought with you - "I can learn to listen deeply to my body's messages, and trust my own inner knowing. I can seek help if needed from trusted friends, relatives, and experts. It's OK to ask for help."
do you think you might find yourself engaging with the experience differently?
thank you yes i like the new thought a lot
i think yes i'll be able to
fantastic! sounds like we have made some solid progress today. how are you feeling now compared to when we first started this conversation?
yea, pretty good. i still feel that inner sensation. but rn it feels more like it's kinda heated up, possibly even slightly morphing in a different way.
and so appreciate the opportunity to explore this very subtle thing in so much depth. all of your questions and insights have been really great! thanks again
i'm really glad to hear that! even though the inner sensation is still there, it sounds like your relationship with it might be beginning to shift in a more positive way
isn't it amazing how just by shifting our perspective a bit, we can start to see things differently
and you're absolutely welcome!

remember to practice your new thought "I can learn to listen deeply to my body's messages, and trust my own inner knowing. I can seek help if needed from trusted friends, relatives, experts. It's OK to ask for help." when you start feeling that sensation again
yes, thanks!
thank you for helping me today :)
take care!
you too, sayonara!
